facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 209 of 1962 and 3 of 1963 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeals Nos. 209 of 1962 and 3 of 1963. Appeals by special leave

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from Patna High Court judgment dated August 30, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 30, 1962, of the Patna High Court in Government Appeal No. 33 of 1959 and Cr. Appeal No. 392 of 1959 respectively.

facts.text: Patna High Court disposed of Government Appeal No. 33 of 1959 and Cr. Appeal No. 392 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: of the Patna High Court in Government Appeal No. 33 of 1959 and Cr. Appeal No. 392 of 1959 respectively. P. Varma, for the appellants

facts.text: Nine persons appealed to Supreme Court after conviction under s. 302/149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: In these two appeals by nine persons, who, have been companyvicted under s. 302/1149, Indian Penal Code, special. leave is limited to one question of law

facts.text: Misari lost his life in the incident.

anchor.surface_text: The person who lost As life was one Misari who was related to some of the accused persons. In the past there were other incidents.

facts.text: In 1955, Ajablal was murdered and some present accused were prosecuted but acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: In 1955 one Ajablal was murdered and some of the present accused were prosecuted but were acquitted. Subsequently, one Baldeo Sharma was murdered

facts.text: Baldeo Sharma was murdered subsequently, and some prosecution witnesses charged; appeal pending in Patna High Court as of August 30, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, one Baldeo Sharma was murdered and some of the prosecution witnesses in this case were charged with that offence. At the time of the judgment under appeal  August 30, 1962  an appeal was pending

facts.text: Present occurrence took place on April 24, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The present occurrence took place on April 24, 1958. The prosecution case is that Misari was going in the morning to call laborers when he was attacked

facts.text: Misari was attacked by appellants with diverse weapons while going to call laborers in the morning.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case is that Misari was going in the morning to call laborers when he was attacked by the appellants with diverse weapons. He died as a result of his injuries

facts.text: Misari died as a result of his injuries; case registered under s. 302 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: He died as a result of his injuries and a case was registered under s. 302, Indian Penal Code. The appellants were charged at the trial alternatively under s. 302/149

facts.text: Appellants charged alternatively under s. 302/149 and 302/34 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were charged at the trial alternatively under s. 302/149 and 302 /34, Indian Penal Code. The Additional Sessions Judge, Monahyr companyvicted three

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge convicted three appellants on both charges, sentenced to life imprisonment on first charge; acquitted remaining accused.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Sessions Judge, Monahyr companyvicted three of the appellant,-, on both the charges, sentencing them to imprisonment for life on the first charge only. The remaining accused were acquitted.

facts.text: Appeals by convicted accused and State Government against acquittals heard together and disposed by common judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by those who were companyvicted and by the State Government against the acquittal of the others were heard together and were disposed of by the companymon judgment number under appeal.

facts.text: Patna High Court allowed State appeal, dismissed accused appeals; all original accused convicted under s. 302/149 IPC and sentenced to life imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal of the State Government was allowed and that of the three companyvicted accused was dismissed. As a result all the original accused were companyvicted under s. 302/1.49

facts.text: During High Court appeals, State counsel raised point that trial bad for no charge under s. 147 or 148.

anchor.surface_text: During the hearing of the appeals a point was raised by the State companynsel in the appeal by the State that the trial was bad inasmuch as numbercharge under S. 147 or s. 148 had been framed.

facts.text: Patna High Court Full Bench held charges under ss. 147 and 148 not necessary for conviction under s. 302/149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the judgment under appeal that there was a difference of opinion on this point in the High Court at Patna and the appeals in the High Court were disposed of by a Full Bench which held that charges under ss. 147 and 148 were number necessary

facts.text: Supreme Court special leave limited to question whether accused could be convicted under 302/149 without charge under 147 or 148.

anchor.surface_text: special. leave is limited to one question of law, namely, whether the accused companyld be legally companyvicted under the above sections when they were number charged and companyvicted under S. 147 or s. 148 of the Indian Penal Code ?

facts.text: Misari related to some accused persons.

anchor.surface_text: The person who lost As life was one Misari who was related to some of the accused persons.

facts.text: Supreme Court confirms Patna High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the companyclusion of the Full Bench and therefore companyfirm the judgment under appeal.

facts.text: Prosecution proved unlawful assembly with common object to murder Misari and membership of each appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution has proved the existence of an unlawful assembly, its companymon object which was murder of Misari and the member-,hip of each of the appellants. Nothing more was necessary.

arguments.claim: The scheme of Chapter VI IPC (ss. 141-149) shows vicarious liability arises under ss. 146/149 without requiring prior charges under ss. 147/148

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of the Chapter may be examined. Section 141 defines an unlawful assembly as an assembly of five or more persons the companymon object of which is inter alia to companymit an offence. There are five clauses which describe the many kinds of companymon objects

arguments.claim: Ingredients of s. 143 are implied in s. 147, and ingredients of s. 147 are implied in a charge under s. 149; no separate charges obligatory

anchor.surface_text: The fallacy in the cases which hold that a charge under s. 147 is companypulsory arises because they overlook that the ingredients of s. 143 are implied in s. 147 and the ingredients of s. 147 are implied when a charge under s. 149 is included.

arguments.claim: It is not obligatory to charge under s. 143/147 when charging under s. 147/148 or s. 149 with other offences; these sections are implied

anchor.surface_text: It is number obligatory to charge a person under s. 143, or s. 144 when charging him with S. 147 or s. 148. Similarly, it is number obligatory to charge a person under s. 143 or s. 147 when charging him for an offence with the aid of s. 149. These sections are implied.

holdings.text: Charges under ss. 147 and 148 are not necessary before conviction under s. 302, Indian Penal Code could be made with the aid of s. 149, Indian Penal Code

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the judgment under appeal that there was a difference of opinion on this point in the High Court at Patna and the appeals in the High Court were disposed of by a Full Bench which held that charges under ss. 147 and 148 were not necessary before conviction under s. 302,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court agrees with Patna High Court Full Bench after analyzing scheme of Chapter VI IPC

holdings.text: It is not obligatory to charge a person under s. 147 or s. 148 before s. 149 can be utilized; Section 149 does not state this to be a condition precedent for its own application and no other section prescribes this procedure

anchor.surface_text: This being the scheme, is it obligatory to charge a person under s. 147 or s. 148 before s. 149 can be utilized ? Section 149 does not state this to be a condition precedent for its own application. No other section prescribes this procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of s.149 and absence of any prescriptive section requiring prior charges

holdings.text: It is not obligatory to charge a person under s. 143 or s. 147 when charging him for an offence with the aid of s. 149. These sections are implied

anchor.surface_text: It is not obligatory to charge a person under s. 143, or s. 144 when charging him with S. 147 or s. 148. Similarly, it is not obligatory to charge a person under s. 143 or s. 147 when charging him for an offence with the aid of s. 149. These sections are implied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ingredients of lower sections (143,147) implied in charge under s.149; analogous to non-requirement in 147/148 charges

holdings.text: The ingredients of s. 143 are implied in s. 147 and the ingredients of s. 147 are implied when a charge under s. 149 is included

anchor.surface_text: The fallacy in the cases which hold that a charge under s. 147 is compulsory arises because they overlook that the ingredients of s. 143 are implied in s. 147 and the ingredients of s. 147 are implied when a charge under s. 149 is included.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical implication of ingredients through statutory scheme; distinguishes contrary precedents

holdings.text: The charges framed against the appellants contain all the necessary ingredients to bring home to each member of the unlawful assembly the offence of murder with the aid of s. 149

anchor.surface_text: The charges that are framed against the appellants and which we have reproduced earlier, contain all the necessary ingredients to bring home to each member of the unlawful assembly the offence of murder with the aid of s. 149. The prosecution has proved the existence of an unlawful assembly,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application to facts: charges suffice, prosecution proved unlawful assembly, common object of murder, membership

holdings.text: The prosecution has proved the existence of an unlawful assembly, its common object which was murder of Misari and the membership of each of the appellants. Nothing more was necessary

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution has proved the existence of an unlawful assembly, its common object which was murder of Misari and the membership of each of the appellants. Nothing more was necessary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual finding on proof of s.149 elements sufficient for conviction

holdings.text: If a charge had been framed under S. 147 or 148 and that charge had failed against any of the accused then s. 149 could not have been used against him

anchor.surface_text: of course, if a charge had been framed under S. 147 or 148 and that charge had failed against any of the accused then s. 149 could not have been used against him. The area which is common to ss. 147 and 149 is the substratum on which different degrees of liability are built

holdings.reasoning_summary: Vicarious liability under s.149 requires proof of substratum (unlawful assembly etc.); failure of prior charge would negate it
